However, on their return the X-Men escape the Reavers through the [[Siege Perilous (comics)|Siege Perilous]]. Only Wolverine, who is on a leave of absence in [[Madripoor]], remains. Once he returns, they capture him, and proceed to torture and [[crucify]] him. Wolverine escapes the Reavers with the aid of [[Jubilee (comics)|Jubilee]]. The Reavers then attack the [[Muir Island]] Mutant Research Center, theorizing that it is Wolverine's most likely destination. They fight [[Freedom Force (comics)|Freedom Force]] and [[Moira MacTaggart]]'s alternate X-Men team, and kill [[Stonewall (comics)|Stonewall]] and [[Sunder (comics)|Sunder]]. During the assault on Muir Island, Skullbuster is rendered inoperative by sniper fire from [[Forge (comics)|Forge]].''Uncanny X-Men'' #252-255 Donald Pierce rescues a gravely wounded pilot named [[Skullbuster#Cylla Markham Skullbuster II|Cylla Markham]], who agrees to be converted into a cyborg.''Uncanny X-Men'' #261 Around this time, Bonebreaker, Reese, and Pretty Boy are dispatched to a New York warehouse after [[Microchip (comics)|Microchip]], an associate of the [[Punisher]], in a self-confessed mistake, infiltrates their computer system. The temporary absence of Gateway gives Punisher and Microchip enough time to evacuate and set up resistance. The warehouse is destroyed, but the two escape through the sewer.''Punisher'', volume 2, #33 The Reavers face off against the Punisher again. In the firefight, the Reavers kill Microchip's cousin. The Punisher sets off auto-destruct charges which cause heavy damage to the three Reavers, particularly Bonebreaker, whose cybernetic lower body is demolished. The Reavers retreat.''Punisher'', volume 2, #34 The Reavers then successfully attack the [[Emma Frost|White Queen]]'s company, Frost Technotics.''Uncanny X-Men'' #262 They capture [[Rogue (comics)|Rogue]], who has returned from inside the Siege Perilous, although Rogue is then rescued by a recreation of [[Ms. Marvel]]. Donald Pierce transforms Cylla Markham into the new Skullbuster (although she usually goes by the name Cylla).''Uncanny X-Men'' #269 Lady Deathstrike later seeks Wolverine in Madripoor and Vancouver. Pierce creates an android named [[Elsie-Dee]] and a Wolverine android double named "[[Albert (comics)|Albert]]" to kill Wolverine. The attempt fails, however, when Elsie-Dee rebels against her programming.''Wolverine'' (vol. 2) #35-39 ===Upstarts and humans=== As part of the [[Upstarts (comics)|Upstarts]]' game, [[Trevor Fitzroy]] dispatches his own [[Sentinel (comics)|Sentinels]] to the Reavers' Australian hideout to kill Pierce and anyone else they find there. In the ensuing battle, only Pierce, Lady Deathstrike and Cylla escape the massacre, Pierce seemingly only making it as far as the Hellfire Club before he is "killed".''Uncanny X-Men'' #281-282 Cylla later resurfaces, allying herself with [[Bloodscream]] in an attempt to murder Wolverine. However, Bloodscream betrays her and sucks the life from her, killing her.''Wolverine'' vol. 2 #77-78 However, most Reavers somehow survive their supposed deaths. They later return to battle the [[X-Treme X-Men]] on behalf of the [[Shadow King]].{{Cite comic|writer=[[Chris Claremont]]|penciller=[[Salvador Larroca]]|story=Queen of Shadows|title=[[X-Treme X-Men]] 2001 Annual|issue=|date=2001|publisher=[[Marvel Comics]]}} Donald Pierce puts together a new group of Reavers, composed of young anti-[[Mutant (Marvel Comics)|mutant]] humans (with the exception of [[Elixir (comics)|Elixir]], who at the time was unaware that he was a mutant).''New Mutants'' vol. 2 #5 (November 2003) They are defeated by [[Karma (comics)|Karma]], Elixir, and a handful of young mutants.''New Mutants'' vol. 2 #6 (December 2003) The group later breaks Pierce out of prison, but with Elixir as bait, they are lured into an ambush and captured by the same five mutants who stopped Pierce when he first betrayed the Hellfire Club's Inner Circle.''New Mutants'' vol. 2 #13 (August 2004) ===Messiah Complex=== [[Image:The New Reavers.jpg|200px|thumb|right|The latest incarnation of the Reavers in Messiah Complex by [[Humberto Ramos]].]] The Reavers return to play a role in the [[X-Men: Messiah Complex|Messiah Complex]] event, under the leadership of Lady Deathstrike.[http://comics.ign.com/articles/827/827571p7.html IGN: X-Men: Messiah Complex - Day Thirteen] Judging from the design of their costumes, as well as their rhetoric in battle, these newest Reavers are simply existing members of the [[Purifiers (Marvel Comics)|Purifiers]] upgraded with cybernetics rather than classic members of the team.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} Deployed as an elite commando unit designed to eliminate organized mutant resistance, the Reavers manage to track down and confront Cable in Alberta, Canada before being attacked by the new X-Force.''New X-Men'' #44-46 In the ensuing battle, Deathstrike and the Reavers are all terminated by Wolverine's strike team, but not before killing the mutant [[Caliban (comics)|Caliban]] and injuring [[Cable (comics)|Cable]]. To this date only Deathstrike's fate was revealed and it remains to be seen whether the Purifiers will be able to upgrade more of their fighters with Reaver technology to replace the ones lost in Canada.''Uncanny X-Men'' #504 ===Cable and X-Force=== The Reavers play a small role in ''[[Cable and X-Force]]'' - Volume 4. Pretty Boy, Bonebreaker, Skullbuster (female), and Skullbuster (male) are quickly dispatched by Hope Summers and Cable before being able to deploy an ICBM.{{issue|date=April 2016}} ===Hunt for Wolverine=== Donald Pierce later leads a new group of Reavers, composed of Star and Shine whom together go by the Starshine moniker, Pretty Boy, Skullbuster (Cylla Markham) and Bonebreaker. They were able to find the place where the X-Men had hidden Wolverine's metal-encased body until they were found by an X-Men. During the battle, Wolverine's adamantium shell was broken and to the Reavers surprise it was empty. The X-Men eventually defeated the Reavers and delivered them to Alpha Flight. Only Starshine was able to evade capture and contacted Lady Deathstrike about their findings.''Hunt for Wolverine'' #1 ==Known members== ===First Team=== * [[Bonebreaker]] * [[Skullbuster]] * [[Pretty Boy (comics)|Pretty Boy]] * Various unnamed other members (deceased or reincarnated) ===Second Team=== * Donald Pierce (leader) * [[Lady Deathstrike]] * Wade Cole (deceased) * [[List of Marvel Comics characters: M#Angelo Macon|Angelo Macon]] (deceased) * Murray Reese (deceased) * Bonebreaker (arrested) * Skullbuster * Skullbuster ([[Cylla Markham|Cylla]]) * Pretty Boy (arrested) ===Third Team=== * Donald Pierce (leader) * Elixir (quit) * Duncan * Various unnamed other members ===Fourth Team=== * Lady Deathstrike (leader) * Various unnamed other members (all presumed deceased) ===Fifth Team=== * Donald Pierce (leader) * Starshine, a duo of Japanese young women that together function as the Reavers ship: ** Star appears to have the ability to fuse with machinery which she can use as her own body ** Shine appears to possess psionic powers * Pretty Boy * Skullbuster (Cylla) * Bonebreaker * Lady Deathstrike (defected) ==Other versions== ===Age of Apocalypse=== In the [[Age of Apocalypse]], Reavers were a band of human traitors serving [[Apocalypse (comics)#Age of Apocalypse|Apocalypse]]. They have been enhanced with Apocalypse's techno-organic virus which allows them to merge with both organic and mechanical materials.''Weapon X'' #1-4 ===Ultimate Marvel=== Rather than being a specific team of supervillains, the [[Ultimate Marvel|Ultimate]] version of the Reavers are human [[gladiator]]s who have undergone surgery to become cyborgs for the specific purpose of hunting down mutants on live television. They are led by the deranged Mutant-hunter [[Deadpool (comics)#Ultimate Deadpool|Sgt. Wade "Wadey" Wilson aka Deadpool]]. Some do retain the names of the Earth-616 Reavers, such as 'Bonebreaker'. Another known one is named 'Cruise'.''Ultimate Spider-Man'' #92 ==In other media== ===Television=== * The Reavers make an appearance in the two-part ''[[X-Men (TV series)|X-Men]]'' episodes "Out of the Past". Known members are Lady Deathstrike, Bonebreaker, Pretty Boy, Murray Reese, Skullbuster, and Wade Cole. The Reavers do a trick that leads Wolverine into the tunnels where they plan to use him to open an alien ship that Lady Deathstrike found. When the ship is opened, the alien inside ends up sucking the lifeforce out of the Reavers. Wolverine and Lady Deathstrike had to work together to defeat the alien. Once the alien is defeated, the lifeforce of the Reavers are returned to their bodies. Donald Pierce would instead be a member of the ''Inner Circle'' (the alternate name in this TV series for the ''[[Hellfire Club (comics)|Hellfire Club]]'') instead in this continuity, as seen in the four part "Dark Phoenix Saga" storyline. * The Reavers appeared in ''[[Wolverine and the X-Men (TV series)|Wolverine and the X-Men]]'', with their vocal effects provided by [[Charlie Adler]] in "X-Calibre" and by [[Steven Blum]] in "Hunting Grounds." They are shown as servants of Mojo and Spiral and the identified Reavers are Murray Reese, Wade Cole, Angelo Macon, and a female named Ricochet. ===Film=== * The Reavers appear in ''[[Logan (2017 film)|Logan]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/movies/x-men/feature/a795439/wolverine-x-men-who-are-the-reavers/|title=Logan and the X-Men: who are the Reavers and what do they want with Wolverine?|last=Armitage|first=Hugh|work=[[Digital Spy]]|date=October 19, 2016|accessdate=October 30, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/logan-reavers-confirmed-wolverine-3-939244|title='Logan' Photo Confirms Appearance of Classic X-Men Villains|last=Couch|first=Aaron|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=October 18, 2016|accessdate=October 30, 2016}} The known members are Bonebreaker, Pretty Boy, Angelo Macon, Danny Rhodes, and Mohawk. In the year 2029, the Reavers are an enhanced security force for the Transigen Project led by Donald Pierce and are all under the employ of [[Zander Rice|Dr. Zander Rice]] who heads up the Transigen Project. ===Video games=== * The Reavers (via Bonebreaker) appear as an army of soldiers for Magneto in the ''[[X-Men (1992 video game)|1992 X-Men arcade game]]. * The Reavers also appear in Capcom's ''[[The Punisher (1993 video game)|The Punisher]]'' arcade game, with Bonebreaker as a stage boss and many Pretty Boy cyborgs in different stages. * The Reavers appear in [[Strider Hiryu]]'s ending in ''[[Ultimate Marvel vs. Capcom 3]]''. * The Reavers appear in ''[[Marvel Heroes (video game)|Marvel Heroes]]''. While Lady Deathstrike and Bonebreaker are known members, the foot sodliers of the Reavers consist of Dr. Reaversteins, Mighty Max, Reaver Berserkers, Reaver Blitzkriegs, Reaver Hellhounds, Reaver Maniacs, Reaver Psychotics, and Reaver Savages. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.marvel.com/universe/Reavers Reavers] at Marvel.com {{X-Men}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Reavers (Comics)}} [[Category:Characters created by Chris Claremont]] [[Category:Characters created by Marc Silvestri]] [[Category:Fictional cyborgs]] [[Category:Marvel Comics supervillain teams]]

page.title: Reportedly haunted locations in the District of Columbia

revision.text:
{{good article}} [[File:US Capitol Building at night Jan 2006.jpg|right|thumb|300px|The [[United States Capitol]], one of many places in Washington said to be haunted]] There are a number of reportedly haunted locations in [[Washington, D.C.]] The city is the [[Capital (political)|capital]] of the United States, and was founded (pursuant to an [[Act of Congress]]) on July 16, 1790. The City of Washington was originally a separate municipality within the Territory of Columbia until an act of Congress in 1871 effectively merged George Town, the City of Washington, and the Territory of Columbia into a single entity called the District of Columbia. Washington, D.C., has been the site of military battles, deadly duels, assassinations, untimely deaths, and associated tragedies. {{Paranormal |state=collapsed}} Washington's haunted history is so well known that some of its haunted locations were featured in a 2006 documentary, ''America's Haunted Houses,'' on the [[A&E Network|A&E cable network]]. Novelist [[Dan Brown]] mentioned them prominently in his 2009 novel, ''[[The Lost Symbol]]''. Notable purportedly haunted locations include the [[United States Capitol]], [[Capitol Hill, Washington, D.C.|Capitol Hill]], the [[White House]], [[Lafayette Square, Washington, D.C.|Lafayette Square]] and nearby buildings, [[Independence Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|Independence Avenue SW]], [[The Octagon House]], [[Chinatown, Washington, D.C.|Chinatown]], the [[National Theatre (Washington, D.C.)|National Theatre]], [[Hay–Adams Hotel]], [[Woodrow Wilson House (Washington, D.C.)|Woodrow Wilson House]], [[Omni Shoreham Hotel]], and many others.
The [[United States Capitol]] is reputedly haunted by many past representatives of the [[United States House of Representatives]] and government officials, officers who served during the [[American Revolutionary War]], workers who died during its construction and a "demon black cat" that is said to make appearances just before national tragedies or changes in Presidential administration. A very high number of apparitions of deceased [[Presidents of the United States|American presidents]] have been reported in the White House, the most famous of which is [[Abraham Lincoln]], reported even by later presidents such as [[Harry S. Truman]], and apparitions of presidents [[Thomas Jefferson]], [[Andrew Jackson]], and [[John Tyler]] have all been witnessed, as have the spirits of many [[First Lady of the United States|First Ladies]].
The President's Park, Lafayette Park, and nearby buildings are reported to be home to ghosts such as [[Philip Barton Key II]] and [[Stephen Decatur]] who died there following pistol duels. The Octagon is supposedly one of the most haunted buildings in D.C., with sightings of its past occupants and African American slaves who once worked there. [[National Theatre (Washington, D.C.)|The National Theatre]] is said to be haunted by the ghost of actor John McCullough, who was murdered in the 1880s by a fellow thespian. Hay–Adams Hotel is claimed to be host to the ghost of [[Marian Hooper Adams|Marian "Clover" Hooper Adams]], the wife of [[Henry Brooks Adams]], the celebrated 19th-century American journalist, historian and novelist, who was the grandson of [[John Quincy Adams]], and the Woodrow Wilson House is allegedly haunted by former president [[Woodrow Wilson]] himself who spent his final years in illness there before dying in his bedroom in 1924. Houses in the [[Georgetown, Washington, D.C.|Georgetown]] area of the city are reported to be haunted by figures from colonial times, including slaves, merchants and children. Staff and guests of the Omni Shoreham Hotel have told of stories of faint voices, cold breezes, and doors slamming shut and opening and televisions and lights turning on and off of their own accord.
==Capitol Hill==
===The Capitol=== The [[United States Capitol]] is considered one of the most haunted buildings in Washington.<ref name="French">[https://books.google.com/books?id=wvxJAAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_v2_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q=&f=false French, Joseph Lewis. ''The Best Ghost Stories.''] New York: Boni and Liveright, Inc., 1919.</ref><ref name="Mather">[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2003/10/31/national/main581269.shtml Cosgrove-Mather, Bootie. "Haunted House On The Hill."] CBS News. October 31, 2003.</ref> The first apparition to be seen there was in the 1860s as the Capitol was being completed.<ref name="Alexander">Alexander, John. ''Ghosts: Washington's Most Famous Ghost Stories.'' Arlington, Va.: The Washington Book Trading Co., 1988. {{ISBN|978-0-91516807-1}}</ref> Several spirits are said to haunt the Capitol due to tragedies associated with its construction. One such ghost is said to be that of a worker who died after a fall during the construction of the rotunda, and who now is occasionally seen floating beneath the dome carrying a tray of woodworking tools.<ref name="Alexander" /> Another spirit is allegedly a [[Stonemasonry|stonemason]] who died (crushed to death beneath a wall which collapsed, or murdered by a co-worker) and is seen in the Old Senate chambers or passing through a wall in the basement beneath the Senate.<ref name="Norman">Norman, Michael and Scott, Beth. ''Historic Haunted America.'' Reprint ed. New York: Macmillan, 2007. {{ISBN|0-7653-1970-5}}</ref>
[[File:National Statuary Hall Collection.jpg|thumb|National Statuary Hall, said to be haunted by a number of former members of Congress]] Many politicians with strong personalities and a powerful attachment to the institution of Congress are reputed still to roam the halls of Congress long after their deaths. The shades of [[United States House of Representatives|Representative]] [[Joseph Gurney Cannon|Joseph Cannon]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]-[[Illinois|Ill.]] and [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker]] from 1903 to 1911) and Rep. [[Champ Clark]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]-[[Missouri|Mo.]] and Speaker from 1911 to 1919) are claimed to occasionally return to the dark chamber of the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] after midnight and, after a loud rap from a [[gavel]], resume the strong, angry debates they once had in life.<ref name="Mather" /> Members of the [[United States Capitol Police]] have claimed to have seen Senator (and from 1852 to 1854, [[United States House of Representatives|Representative]]) [[Thomas Hart Benton (senator)|Thomas Hart Benton]] sitting at a desk in [[National Statuary Hall]], although it has not been used as a legislative chamber since 1857.<ref name="GhostTown" /><ref>Bardes, Barbara A.; Shelley, Mack C.; and [[Steffen Schmidt|Schmidt, Steffen W.]] ''American Government and Politics Today: The Essentials.'' 15th ed. Florence, Ky.: Cengage Learning, 2008. {{ISBN|0-495-57170-9}}</ref> Steve Livengood, chief tour guide for the [[United States Capitol Historical Society]], says he has seen the ghost of former Representative [[Wilbur Mills]] (D-[[Arkansas|Ark.]]) near Mills' former office late at night.<ref name="Jordan">[http://www.rollcall.com/issues/55_5/ath/36682-1.html Jordan, Elizabeth. "Ghosts Wander the Hill."] ''[[Roll Call]].'' July 13, 2009.</ref> [[Pierre Charles L'Enfant]], although not a politician, was a [[brevet (military)|brevet]] [[Major (United States)|Major]] during the [[American Revolutionary War]] who served with [[George Washington]] at [[Valley Forge]].<ref name="Jusserand">Jusserand, Jean Jules. ''Major L'Enfant and the Federal City.'' New York: Charles Scribner's Sons, 1916; Bowling, Kenneth R. ''Peter Charles L'Enfant: Vision, Honor, and Male Friendship in the Early American Republic.'' Washington, D.C.: George Washington University, 2002. OCLC 51037796</ref> In 1791, L'Enfant was appointed architect and planner of the new city of Washington in the District of Columbia.<ref name="Jusserand" /> Although L'Enfant submitted grandiose plans for the new capital city, his plans were never fully adopted and President Washington dismissed him.<ref name="Jusserand" /> L'Enfant spent much of the rest of his life attempting to wrest a monetary payment from Congress, and he died in poverty in 1825.<ref name="Jusserand" /> Eyewitnesses, however, claim to have seen his spirit walking through the Capitol, head down, murmuring to himself, with the plans for the capital city tucked under his arm.<ref name="Fishbait">Miller, William and Leighton, Frances Spatz. ''Fishbait: The Memoirs of the Congressional Doorkeeper.'' New York: Prentice-Hall, 1977. {{ISBN|0-13-320416-2}}</ref>
The Capitol has also been witness to murder and death. Rep. [[William P. Taulbee]] had been a congressman from [[Kentucky]] from 1884 to 1888.<ref name="Clerk">[http://history.house.gov/HistoricalHighlight/Detail/35553 Office of the Clerk. United States House of Representatives. "The Death of Congressman William Taulbee on the Steps of the U.S. Capitol." No date.] Accessed 2009-10-09; Kessler, Ronald. ''Inside Congress: The Shocking Scandals, Corruption, and Abuse of Power Behind the Scenes on Capitol Hill.'' Reprint ed. New York: Simon and Schuster, 1998. {{ISBN|0-671-00386-0}}; [[Sherrod Brown|Brown, Sherrod]]. ''Congress From the Inside: Observations From the Majority and the Minority.'' 2d ed. Kent, Ohio: Kent State University Press, 2000. {{ISBN|0-87338-676-0}}; Remini, Robert Vincent. ''The House: The History of the House of Representatives.'' New York: HarperCollins, 2006. {{ISBN|0-06-088434-7}}; [[James C. Klotter|Klotter, James C.]] ''Kentucky Justice, Southern Honor, and American Manhood: Understanding the Life and Death of Richard Reid.'' Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 2003. {{ISBN|0-8071-2857-0}}</ref> Charles E. Kincaid, a journalist for ''[[The Louisville Times]]'', had accused Taulbee of [[adultery]] and involvement in a [[United States Patent and Trademark Office|Patent Office]] scandal, which had ruined Taulbee's political career.<ref name="Clerk" /> On February 28, 1890, the ex-congressman and the reporter ran into one another in the Capitol, and Taulbee assaulted and embarrassed Kincaid by tweaking the much smaller man's nose.<ref name="Clerk" /> Kincaid ran home, grabbed a pistol, and, when he encountered Taulbee on a marble staircase leading from the House chamber down to the dining room, shot him in the face just below Taulbee's left eye.<ref name="Clerk" /> Taulbee died two weeks later, and Kincaid was acquitted after claiming self-defense.<ref name="Clerk" /> Journalists and others claim that whenever a reporter slips on these steps, Taulbee's ghost briefly appears.<ref>Taylor, Troy. ''Wicked Washington: Mysteries, Murder & Mayhem in America's Capital.'' Charleston, S.C.: The History Press, 2007. {{ISBN|1-59629-302-0}}</ref> Former President and then-Rep. [[John Quincy Adams]] suffered a [[stroke]] at his desk in the House chamber on February 21, 1848, and was taken into the Speaker's Room.<ref name="Widmer">Widmer, Edward L. ''Ark of the Liberties: America and the World.'' New York: Hill and Wang. {{ISBN|978-0-8090-2735-4}}; Remini, Robert Vincent. ''John Quincy Adams.'' New York: Times Books, 2002. {{ISBN|0-8050-6939-9}}</ref> His physical condition was too precarious to permit him to be moved, and he died at the Capitol two days later.<ref name="Widmer" /> Many people claim to have heard Adams' ghost denouncing slavery late at night in National Statuary Hall, and one Congressional staff member claims that by standing in the spot where Adams' desk once stood a person can still hear the former president's ghostly whisper.<ref name="Mather" /> [[James A. Garfield]] was a member of the House from 1863 to 1881 before assuming the Presidency in March 1881.<ref name="Reeves">Reeves, Thomas C. ''Gentleman Boss.'' New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 1975. {{ISBN|0-394-46095-2}}</ref> Garfield was shot by [[Charles J. Guiteau]], a disgruntled office seeker, on July 2, 1881, at 9:30 a.m. as he walked through the Sixth Street Station of the [[Baltimore and Potomac Railroad]] in Washington, D.C.<ref name="Reeves" /> Garfield died of heart failure brought about by [[blood poisoning]] (itself caused by poor medical care) on September 19, 1881, while recuperating at a beach house near [[Long Branch, New Jersey]].<ref name="Reeves" /> Witnesses have seen Garfield's specter walking solemnly through the halls of Congress.<ref name="Ogden" />
Not all Capitol hauntings are related to people who worked there. The "[[Demon Cat]]" is alleged to prowl the halls of Congress, and make appearances just before a national tragedy or change in Presidential administration.<ref name="Rainbolt">Rainbolt, Dusty. ''Ghost Cats: Human Encounters with Feline Spirits.'' Guilford, Conn.: Globe Pequot, 2007. {{ISBN|1-59921-004-5}} and [http://thehill.com/capital-living/24150-haunted-house--and-senate Yager, Jordy. "Haunted House — and Senate."] ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]].'' March 3, 2009.</ref> It was first seen in the early part of the 19th century, and a night watchman shot at it in 1862.<ref name="French" /> It has also been seen by other night watchmen and members of the Capitol Police.<ref name="Tischler" /> It appeared before the assassination of President [[Abraham Lincoln]], the [[Wall Street Crash of 1929|October 1929 stock market crash]], and the assassination of President [[John F. Kennedy]].<ref name="Jordan" /> The cat has not only been seen in the halls, but has repeatedly appeared in [[Washington's Tomb (United States Capitol)|Washington's Tomb]].<ref name="Hauck" /> The Tomb (two levels below the [[United States Capitol crypt|crypt]] beneath the Capitol Rotunda) was an original feature of the Capitol, planned as a resting place for George Washington and members of his family.<ref name="Crypt">Moore, John Leo. ''Speaking of Washington: Facts, Firsts, and Folklore.'' Washington, D.C.: Congressional Quarterly, 1993. {{ISBN|0-87187-762-7}}; Aikman, Lonnelle. ''We, the People: The Story of the United States Capitol, Its Past and Its Promise.'' 13th ed. Washington, D.C.: United States Capitol Historical Society, 1985. {{ISBN|0-916200-06-X}}</ref> The Washington family politely declined the offer.<ref name="Crypt" /> The Tomb stands empty, although from 1865 to 2009 (when it was moved to the [[United States Capitol Visitor Center]]) the [[Lincoln catafalque]] was stored there.<ref name="Crypt" /> The specters of at least two soldiers are also said to haunt the Capitol. A few eyewitnesses have claimed that whenever an individual [[Lying in state|lies in state]] in the Capitol Rotunda, a World War I [[doughboy]] momentarily appears, salutes, then disappears.<ref name="Hauck" /> A second apparition, which eyewitnesses say is the ghost of an American Revolutionary War soldier, has also appeared at the Washington Tomb. According to several stories, the soldier appears, moves around the Lincoln catafalque, and then passes out the door into the hallway before disappearing.<ref name="Alexander" />
===Capitol Hill=== [[File:SilentDrillPlatoon-1.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Commandant's House at the Marine Corps Barracks, allegedly haunted by the ghost of the first Commandant of the U.S. Marine Corps]] [[Capitol Hill, Washington, D.C.|Capitol Hill]] is one of the largest and most densely populated neighborhoods in Washington, D.C. It is bounded by F Street NE on the north and [[Interstate 695 (District of Columbia)|Southeast/Southwest Freeway]] on the south. The U.S. Capitol marks its western boundary, while the [[Anacostia River]] is its eastern limit. Although Capitol Hill has been home to many of the city's powerful, its hauntings appear to be few. One ghost, however, is said to haunt First Street NE. [[Joseph Holt]] was [[Judge Advocate General's Corps, United States Army|Judge Advocate General]] of the [[United States Army]] from 1862 to 1875.<ref name="Holt">"Holt, Joseph (1804–1894)." In ''Andrew Johnson: A Biographical Companion.'' Glenna R. Schroeder-Lein and Richard Zuczek, eds. Santa Barbara, Calif.: ABC-CLIO, 2001. {{ISBN|1-57607-030-1}}</ref> He presided over the [[Abraham Lincoln assassination|trials of the Lincoln assassination conspirators]].<ref name="Holt" /> During the trials, accused conspirators Dr. [[Samuel Mudd]] (who treated [[John Wilkes Booth]]'s broken leg) and [[Mary Surratt]] (at whose downtown [[Mary E. Surratt Boarding House|boarding house]] the conspirators met) were held at the [[Old Capitol Prison]] opposite the U.S. Capitol (the modern day [[United States Supreme Court Building]] stands on the site today).<ref>Green, Constance M. ''Washington: Village and Capital, 1800–1878.'' Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press, 1962.</ref><ref name="Chamlee">Chamlee, Roy Z. ''Lincoln's Assassins: A Complete Account of Their Capture, Trial, and Punishment.'' Jefferson, N.C.: McFarland, 1990. {{ISBN|0-89950-420-5}}</ref> After Holt retired, he allegedly became a recluse in his Capitol Hill home.<ref name="Cohen">Cohen, Daniel. ''Civil War Ghosts.'' New York: Scholastic Inc., 1999. {{ISBN|0-439-05387-0}}</ref> Although the Holt house no longer exists, local residents have told stories of Holt's ghost walking down First Street NE in a blue suit and cape, pondering the guilt of Mudd and Surrat as he heads for the site of the Old Capitol Prison.<ref name="Cohen" />
Capitol Hill's other hauntings are associated with the two military installations in that part of the city. At the official residence of the Commandant of the [[Marine Barracks, Washington, D.C.|Marine Corps Barracks and Parade Ground]] on 8th Street SE, there are stories which talk about rustling papers, the sound of a man pacing, and the appearance of the ghostly image of [[Samuel Nicholas]], the first [[Commandant of the Marine Corps]].<ref name="Caggiula">Caggiula, Samuel M.; Brackett, Beverly; and King, Gilbert. ''City in Time: Washington.'' New York: Sterling Publishing Company, 2008. {{ISBN|1-4027-3609-6}}</ref> At the nearby [[Washington Navy Yard]] at 8th Street SE and [[M Street (Washington, D.C.)|M Street SE]], the ghost of [[Commodore (United States)|Commodore]] [[Thomas Tingey]] is said to stare out of the upper windows of the [[Tingey House]] (the traditional residence of the Commander of the Navy Yard).<ref>Peck, Taylor. ''Round-Shot to Rockets: A History of the Washington Navy Yard and U.S. Naval Gun Factory.'' Annapolis: United States Naval Institute, 1949.</ref> Local residents and press reports also tell stories about "Old Howard," a cantankerous former U.S. Marine who lived in the 1860s in a two-story house between G and I Streets SE who now haunts it, harassing the occupants and acting much like a [[poltergeist]].<ref name="Hauck" />
==White House and President's Park==
===White House=== [[File:WHClintonEastroom.jpg|thumb|The East Room of the White House, where Abigail Adams once hung her laundry and where her spirit may still appear]] The [[White House]] is the oldest building on [[President's Park]]. An integral part of the planned city that is Washington, D.C., a design was chosen and construction begun in 1792, and the building (although unfinished) was opened for occupancy on November 1, 1800.<ref name="Whitcomb">Whitcomb, Claire. ''Real Life at the White House: 200 Years of Daily Life at America's Most Famous Residence.'' New York: Routledge, 2002. {{ISBN|0-415-93951-8}}</ref> The first people to occupy the building were President [[John Adams]] and his wife, [[Abigail Adams|Abigail]].<ref name="Whitcomb" /> Parts of the mansion were unfinished, including the cavernous [[East Room]].<ref name="Gould">Gould, Lewis L. ''American First Ladies: Their Lives and Their Legacy.'' 2d ed. Florence, Ky.: Taylor & Francis, 2001. {{ISBN|0-415-93021-9}}</ref> With no running water (it was not installed until 1834), water had to be brought into the house by jug and heated for bathing or laundry to be done.<ref name="Sferrazza">Anthony, Carl Sferrazza. ''America's First Families: An Inside View of 200 Years of Private Life in the White House.'' New York: Simon and Schuster, 2000. {{ISBN|0-684-86442-8}}</ref> Abigail Adams often hung the family's laundry up to dry in the drafty East Room.<ref name="Gould" /> The ghost of Abigail Adams has been seen since shortly after her death in 1818, arms extended as if she were still carrying laundry into the East Room, accompanied by the smell of soap or damp clothing.<ref name="GhostTown">[http://archives.cnn.com/2000/ALLPOLITICS/stories/10/24/life.ghosts.reut/ "With Election Looming, Washington Is A Ghost Town – Literally."] ''[[Reuters]].'' October 24, 2000.</ref> Household staff in the [[William Howard Taft|Taft administration]] even observed her walking through walls.<ref>Holzer, Hans. ''Hans Holzer's Haunted America.'' Wheaton, Ill.: Barnes & Noble Books, 1993. {{ISBN|1-56619-193-9}}</ref>
====Abraham Lincoln==== [[File:Abraham Lincoln head on shoulders photo portrait.jpg|thumb|left|Abraham Lincoln]] {{main|Lincoln's Ghost}} The White House's most famous alleged apparition is that of Abraham Lincoln. [[Eleanor Roosevelt]] never admitted to having seen Lincoln's ghost, but did say that she felt his presence repeatedly throughout the White House.<ref name="Pederson" /> Mrs. Roosevelt also said that the family dog, [[Fala (dog)|Fala]], would sometimes bark for no reason at what she felt was Lincoln's ghost.<ref name="Ogden" /> President [[Dwight Eisenhower]]'s press secretary, [[James Hagerty]],<ref name="Alexander" /> and Liz Carpenter, press secretary to First Lady [[Lady Bird Johnson]],<ref name="Norman" /> both said they felt Lincoln's presence many times. The former president's footsteps are also said to be heard in the hall outside the [[Lincoln Bedroom]].<ref name="Ogden" /> As reputable an eyewitness as [[Lillian Rogers Parks]] admitted in her autobiography ''[[My Thirty Years Backstairs at the White House]]'' that she had heard them.<ref name="Parks">Parks, Lillian Rogers. ''My Thirty Years Backstairs at the White House.'' New York: Fleet Publishing Corp., 1961.</ref> [[Margaret Truman]], daughter of President [[Harry S. Truman]], said she heard a specter rapping at the door of the Lincoln Bedroom when she stayed there, and believed it was Lincoln.<ref name="Norman" /> President Truman himself was once wakened by raps at the door while spending a night in the Lincoln Bedroom.<ref name="Thomsen" /> Others have actually seen an apparition of the former president. The first person reported to have actually seen Lincoln's spirit was [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]] [[Grace Coolidge]], who said she saw the ghost of Lincoln standing at a window in the [[Yellow Oval Room]] staring out at the Potomac.<ref name="Ogden" /> [[Winston Churchill]],<ref>Garber, Marjorie B. ''Profiling Shakespeare.'' Florence, Ky.: Routledge, 2008. {{ISBN|0-415-96446-6}}</ref> Theodore Roosevelt,<ref>Peterson, Merrill D. ''Lincoln in American Memory.'' Reprint ed. New York: Oxford University Press US, 1995. {{ISBN|0-19-509645-2}}</ref> and [[Maureen Reagan]] and her husband<ref>Reagan, Maureen. ''First Father, First Daughter: A Memoir.'' New York: Little, Brown and Company, 2001. {{ISBN|0-316-73636-8}}</ref> have all claimed to have seen a spectral Lincoln in the White House. A number of staff members of the [[Franklin D. Roosevelt|Franklin D. Roosevelt administration]] claimed to have seen Lincoln's spirit,<ref name="Norman" /> and on one occasion Roosevelt's personal valet ran screaming from the White House claiming he had seen Lincoln's ghost.<ref name="Alexander" /> Perhaps the most famous incident was in 1942 when [[Wilhelmina of the Netherlands|Queen Wilhelmina]] of [[The Netherlands]] heard footsteps outside her White House bedroom and answered a knock on the door, only to see Lincoln in frock coat and top hat standing in front of her (she promptly fainted).<ref name="Belanger">Belanger, Jeff. ''The World's Most Haunted Places: From the Secret Files of Ghostvillage.com.'' New York: Career Press, 2004. {{ISBN|1-56414-764-9}}</ref> Several unnamed eyewitnesses have claimed to have seen the shade of Abraham Lincoln actually lying down on the bed in the Lincoln Bedroom (which was used as a meeting room at the time of his administration), and others have seen Lincoln sit on the edge of the bed and put his boots on.<ref name="Ogden" /> The most famous eyewitness to the latter was Mary Eben, Eleanor Roosevelt's secretary, who saw Lincoln pulling on his boots (after which she ran screaming from the room).<ref name="Pederson">Pederson, William D. and Williams, Frank J. ''Franklin D. Roosevelt and Abraham Lincoln: Competing Perspectives on Two Great Presidencies.'' Armonk, N.Y.: M.E. Sharpe, 2002. {{ISBN|0-7656-1034-5}}</ref><ref name="Blackman">[[W. Haden Blackman]]. ''The Field Guide to North American Hauntings: Everything You Need to Know About Encountering Over 100 Ghosts, Phantoms, and Spectral Entities.'' New York: Three Rivers Press, 1998. {{ISBN|0-609-80021-3}}</ref>
The last sighting of Lincoln's ghost was in the early 1980s, when Tony Savoy, White House operations foreman, came into the White House and saw Lincoln sitting in a chair at the top of some stairs.<ref name="Belanger" />
[[File:WILLIE.JPG|thumb|150px|[[William Wallace Lincoln|Willie Lincoln]], who died in the White House during his father's presidency.]] Abraham Lincoln is not the only Lincoln ghost witnesses claim to have seen in the White House. [[William Wallace Lincoln|Willie Lincoln]], Abraham Lincoln's 11-year-old son, died in the White House of [[typhoid]] on February 20, 1862.<ref>[[David Herbert Donald|Donald, David Herbert]]. ''Lincoln.'' New York: Simon and Schuster, 1995. {{ISBN|0-684-80846-3}}</ref> Willie Lincoln's ghost was first seen in the White House by staff members of the [[Ulysses S. Grant|Grant administration]] in the 1870s, but has appeared as recently as the 1960s (President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]]'s college-age daughter, [[Lynda Bird Johnson Robb]], saw the ghost and claims to have talked to him).<ref name="Norman" />
====Other presidents==== Other presidents, as well as First Ladies, are also said to haunt the White House. Witnesses in the past two centuries have reported that [[Thomas Jefferson]] can be heard playing his violin in the Yellow Oval Room.<ref name="Caggiula" /> President [[Andrew Jackson]] is said to be seen lying on what is thought to be his old bed <ref>Levy, Leonard Williams and Fisher, Louis. ''Encyclopedia of the American Presidency.'' New York: Simon & Schuster, 1994. {{ISBN|0-13-275983-7}}</ref> in the [[Queens' Bedroom]] (also known as the Rose Room), and his guttural laugh has been heard in the White House since the beginning of the 1860s.<ref name="Apkarian" /> First Lady press secretary Liz Carpenter heard the laugh and swore it was Jackson's,<ref name="Alexander" /> and [[Mary Todd Lincoln]] claimed to have heard the stomping and swearing of an invisible presence which she claimed was the uncouth Jackson.<ref name="Leaf">Leaf, Jesse. ''The Everything Family Guide to Washington D.C.: All the Best Hotels, Restaurants, Sites, and Attractions.'' 3rd ed. Cincinnati, Ohio: Everything Books, 2007. {{ISBN|1-59869-287-9}}</ref> White House seamstress Lillian Rogers Parks said she was sewing in the Queen's Bedroom and felt a presence, cold air, and then a hand on the back of her chair.<ref name="Parks" /> She quickly left the room, and for the rest of her time in the White House she refused to enter the room again without at least one other person accompanying her.<ref name="Parks" /> The spirit of [[William Henry Harrison]], it is claimed, haunts the attic,<ref name="Blackman" /> and President [[John Tyler]] allegedly haunts the [[Blue Room (White House)|Blue Room]].<ref name="Hauck" /> First Lady [[Frances Folsom Cleveland Preston|Frances Folsom Cleveland]], who was married to President [[Grover Cleveland]] in the White House's Blue Room in 1886,<ref>Robar, Stephen F. ''Frances Clara Folsom Cleveland.'' New York: Nova Publishers, 2004. {{ISBN|1-59454-150-7}}</ref> is widely claimed to haunt the room where she was married and was seen there after her death in 1947.<ref name="Parks" />
====Non-residents==== The White House is also said to be visited by three specters who did not live there. The first is that of David Burns, who owned the ground on which the White House stands before selling it to the federal government in May 1791, and whose spirit has been seen in Oval Office.<ref name="Norman" /> A reporter told a security guard during the Truman administration that, while standing in the Yellow Oval Room, he heard a faint ghostly voice which said, "I'm Mr. Burns."<ref name="Alexander" /> The second spirit is allegedly that of a British soldier dressed in a [[Red coat (military uniform)|uniform]] from the [[War of 1812]] and carrying a torch.<ref name="Belanger" /> In August 1814, a combined British land and naval force captured Washington, D.C., and [[Burning of Washington|set fire]] to the White House, [[Treasury Building (Washington, D.C.)|Treasury Building]], Capitol, and other buildings in retaliation for the American looting of [[York, Upper Canada]] (now the city of [[Toronto]]) and the burning of the [[Parliament Buildings of Upper Canada]] after the [[Battle of York]] in 1813.<ref name="Burning">Hickey, Donald R. ''The War of 1812: The Forgotten Conflict.'' Urbana, Ill.: University of Illinois Press, 1990. {{ISBN|0-252-06059-8}}; Pitch, Anthony S. ''The Burning of Washington.'' Annapolis: Naval Institute Press, 2000. {{ISBN|1-55750-425-3}}</ref> The fires were put out only when a [[Tropical cyclone|hurricane]] and [[tornado]] passed through Washington the following day, extinguishing the blazes.<ref name="Burning" /> The soldier is claimed to be one of those who burned the White House, or who lost his life the following day in the storm. Another shade alleged to visit the White House is the ghost of Anna Surratt, daughter of convicted Lincoln assassination co-conspirator [[Mary Surratt]], who forced her way into the White House the night before her mother's execution and unsuccessfully begged for her mother's life.<ref name="Chamlee" /><ref>Holloway, Laura Carter. ''The Ladies of the White house: or, In the Home of the Presidents.'' Philadelphia, Pa.: Bradley, Garretson, & Company, 1883; Goodrich, Thomas. ''The Darkest Dawn: Lincoln, Booth, and the Great American Tragedy.'' Bloomington, Ind.: Indiana University Press, 2006. {{ISBN|0-253-21889-6}}</ref> It is claimed by some White House staff that Anna's ghost returns to the White House every July 6, silently banging on the front door to seek entrance and continue her futile pleas for her mother's life.<ref name="Cohen" />
===President's Park and nearby buildings=== [[File:Decatur House north side.jpg|thumb|left|Decatur House on Lafayette Square, showing the bricked-up window out of which the ghost of Stephen Decatur is said to stare]] [[President's Park]], better known as [[Lafayette Square, Washington, D.C.|Lafayette Square]], may have its own spectral resident. [[Philip Barton Key II]] was the son of [[Francis Scott Key]] and the nephew of [[Chief Justice of the United States|Chief Justice]] [[Roger B. Taney]].<ref name="Walther">Walther, Eric H. ''The Shattering of the Union: America in the 1850s.'' New York: Rowman & Littlefield, 2004. {{ISBN|0-8420-2799-8}}</ref> In the spring of 1858, Key began having an affair with [[Teresa Bagioli Sickles]], the wife of his friend [[Daniel Sickles]].<ref>[[Gary W. Gallagher|Gallagher, Gary W.]] ''Three Days at Gettysburg: Essays on Confederate and Union Leadership.'' Kent, Ohio: Kent State University Press, 1999. {{ISBN|0-87338-629-9}}</ref> On February 26, 1859, Sickles learned of the affair.<ref name="Walther" /> The following day, he saw Key in Lafayette Square signalling to his wife.<ref name="Walther" /> Sickles rushed out into the park, drew a pistol, and shot the unarmed Key three times while the other man pleaded for his life.<ref name="Walther" /> Key was taken into the nearby [[Benjamin Ogle Tayloe House]] and died moments later.<ref name="Smith" /> Key's spirit, eyewitnesses and authors claim, now haunts Lafayette Square and can be seen on dark nights near the spot where he was shot.<ref name="Apkarian">Apkarian-Russell, Pamela. ''Washington's Haunted Past: Capital Ghosts of America.'' Charleston, S.C.: The History Press, 2006. {{ISBN|1-59629-181-8}}</ref>
[[Decatur House]] (748 Jackson Place NW) is allegedly haunted by the ghost of [[Stephen Decatur]]. In 1820, Commodore [[James Barron]] challenged Commodore Decatur to a [[duel]] over comments Decatur had made regarding Barron's conduct in the [[Chesapeake-Leopard Affair|''Chesapeake-Leopard'' Affair]] of 1807.<ref>Decatur had served on the court-martial that had found Barron guilty of unpreparedness, and had barred him from a command for the next five years. See: De Kay, James Tertius. ''A Rage for Glory: The Life of Commodore Stephen Decatur, USN.'' New York: Free Press, 2004. {{ISBN|0-7432-4245-9}}</ref> The two men duelled on March 20, and Decatur was mortally wounded in the stomach.<ref name="DeKay">De Kay, ''A Rage for Glory: The Life of Commodore Stephen Decatur, USN,'' 2004.</ref> Decatur was rushed back to his home, and died there on March 22.<ref name="DeKay" /> A year after Decatur's death, his ghost reportedly began appearing at the house—standing in a second floor window looking out at H Street NW or leaving the back door of the house with a box of dueling pistols.<ref name="Ogden">Ogden, Tom. ''The Complete Idiot's Guide to Ghosts and Hauntings.'' New York: Alpha Books, 1999. {{ISBN|0-02-863659-7}}</ref> So many witnesses saw the specter of Decatur that the window was walled up.<ref name="GhostTown" /> Some people have also claimed that they can hear his widow, who became hysterical at his death, weeping in the house.<ref name="Ogden" />
[[File:St John's Episcopal Church DC Presidents Pew south.JPG|thumb|200px|President's pew of St. John's Episcopal Church]] [[St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square|St. John's Episcopal Church]] (1525 H Street NW), built in 1816, is the second-oldest structure on the President's Park.<ref name="Grimmett">Grimmett, Richard F. ''St. John's Church, Lafayette Square: The History and Heritage of the Church of the Presidents, Washington, D.C.'' Minneapolis, Minn.: Hillcrest Publishing Group, 2009. {{ISBN|1-934248-53-3}}</ref> The church has a tradition of a "President's pew," which is reserved for the use of the [[President of the United States]].<ref name="Grimmett" /> The church's bell was purchased from the Revere Company of [[Boston]] (founded by [[Joseph Warren Revere (businessman)|Joseph Warren Revere]], son of [[Paul Revere]]) and installed on November 30, 1822 (where it remains {{as of|2009|lc=y}}).<ref name="Grimmett" /> According to at least two accounts, whenever the bell tolls because of the death of a notable person, six ghostly men in white robes appear in the President's pew at midnight and then vanish.<ref name="Alexander" />
[[File:Dolley Madison House west side.jpg|thumb|left|The west side of the Dolley Madison House, showing the porch (with black railing) where the shade of the former First Lady is said to rock on dark nights]] The Cutts-Madison House (721 Madison Place NW),<ref>Benedetto, Robert; Donovan, Jane; and Du Vall, Kathleen. ''Historical Dictionary of Washington.'' New York: Rowman & Littlefield, 2003. {{ISBN|0-8108-4094-4}}</ref> also known as the Dolley Madison House, was constructed in 1822 by Richard Cutts, brother-in-law of [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]] [[Dolley Madison]].<ref name="Bednar">Bednar, Michael J. ''L'Enfant's Legacy: Public Open Spaces in Washington.'' Baltimore, Md.: Johns Hopkins University Press, 2006. {{ISBN|0-8018-8318-0}}</ref> After ex-[[President of the United States|President]] [[James Madison]] died in 1836, Dolley Madison took up residency in the house and lived there until her death in 1849.<ref name="Smith">Smith, Hal H. "Historic Washington Homes." ''Records of the Columbia Historical Society, Washington.'' 1908.</ref> [[Rear Admiral]] [[Charles Wilkes]] purchased the home in 1851.<ref name="Washburn">Washburn, Wilcomb E. ''The Cosmos Club of Washington: A Centennial History, 1878–1978.'' Washington, D.C.: The Club, 1978.</ref> Wilkes moved the entrance from Madison Place NW to H Street NW, and turned the porch on the west side of the house (facing Madison Place NW) into a window.<ref name="Smith" /> Witnesses from the mid-19th century onward have claimed to have seen the ghost of Dolley Madison rocking in a chair in the space where the porch used to be, smiling at passersby.<ref name="Thomsen">Thomsen, Brian M. ''Oval Office Occult: True Stories of White House Weirdness.'' Kansas City: Andrews McMeel Publishing, 2008. {{ISBN|0-7407-7386-0}}</ref>
==Downtown==
===The Octagon House=== [[File:Octagon House (Washington, D.C.) in 2012.JPG|thumb|The Octagon is supposedly one of the most haunted buildings in D.C.]] [[The Octagon House]] (1799 New York Avenue NW) is reported to be the most haunted home in D.C.<ref>Solomon, Mary Jane; Ruben, Barbard; and Aloisi, Rebecca. ''Insiders' Guide to Washington, D.C.'' 7th ed. Guilford, Conn.: Globe Pequot, 2007. {{ISBN|0-7627-4410-3}}; Roos, Frank John. ''Writings on Early American Architecture: An Annotated List of Books and Articles on Architecture Constructed Before 1860 in the Eastern Half of the United States.'' Columbus, Ohio: The Ohio State University Press, 1943; "Hauntings in the Heart of Washington." ''Washington Post.'' October 24, 2008.</ref> It was built in 1801 by Colonel John Tayloe III.<ref name="McCue">McCue, George. ''The Octagon: Being an Account of a Famous Washington Residence, Its Great Years, Decline & Restoration.'' Washington, D.C.: American Institute of Architects Foundation, 1976.</ref> The Tayloes were a greatly distinguished [[Virginia]] family: His grandfather, Colonel [[John Tayloe I|John Tayloe]] (d. 1747), was a member of the King's Council in Virginia and owner of more than {{convert|3000|acre|km2}} of land (a huge estate at the time), and his father, Colonel [[John Tayloe II]], built the historic [[Mount Airy, Richmond County, Virginia|Mount Airy]] manor house in 1758 and was also a member of the King's Council.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=YjsSAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_v2_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q=&f=false "Old Letters From Virginia County Records."] ''William and Mary College Quarterly Historical Magazine.'' 11:3 (January 1903); Sale, Edith Tunis. ''Manors of Virginia in Colonial Times.'' New York: J.B. Lippincott, 1909; [https://books.google.com/books?id=TpMEAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_v2_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q=&f=false Watson, Winslow Marston. ''In Memoriam: Benjamin Ogle Tayloe.''] Philadelphia, Pa.: Sherman & Co., 1872. For information on the King's Council of Virginia, its constitution, its emigration to America, and its function in Virginia, see: [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1898/07/09/102088909.pdf Warner, Charles Dudley. "Truth About Virginia."] ''New York Times.'' July 9, 1898.</ref> John Tayloe III was a close friend of George Washington's, and Washington convinced Tayloe to build a winter home in the new city of Washington.<ref name="McCue" /> There is some evidence that the walled back yard of The Octagon itself may have served as a [[Slavery|slave market]],<ref>The District of Columbia was "home to the largest slave market in North America", and the city contained four or five very large slave markets as well as numerous smaller "slave pens" in nearly every neighborhood and rural area of the District. See: Bangura, Abdul Karim. ''Historical Political Economy of Washington.'' Latham, Md.: University Press of America, 2000. {{ISBN|0-7618-1707-7}}; Gutheim, Frederick Albert. ''Worthy of the Nation: Washington, DC, From L'Enfant to the National Capital Planning Commission.'' 2d ed. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press, 2006. {{ISBN|0-8018-8328-8}}; Christianson, Scott. ''With Liberty for Some: 500 Years of Imprisonment in America.'' Lebanon, N.H.: University Press of New England, 2000. {{ISBN|1-55553-468-6}}; Goode, James W. ''Capital Losses: A Cultural History of Washington's Destroyed Buildings.'' 2d ed. Washington, D.C.: Smithsonian Books, 2003. {{ISBN|1-58834-105-4}}. For quote, see: De Angelis, Gina. ''It Happened in Washington.'' Guilford, Conn.: Globe Pequot, 2004, {{ISBN|0-7627-2590-7}} p. 49.</ref> and it is well-established that the rear of the building housed the Tayloe family's slaves.<ref>Gutheim, Frederick Albert. ''Worthy of the Nation: Washington, DC, From L'Enfant to the National Capital Planning Commission.'' 2d ed. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press, 2006. {{ISBN|0-8018-8328-8}}</ref> The Tayloe family was exceptionally well-connected, and their home was an important one in the city. After the burning of the White House in the War of 1812, President James and Dolley Madison lived there from September 1814 to October 1815, and Madison signed the [[Treaty of Ghent]] (which ended the war) there in February 1815.<ref>Haas, Irvin. ''Historic Homes of the American Presidents.'' 2d ed. North Chelmsford, Mass.:Courier Dover Publications, 1991. {{ISBN|0-486-26751-2}}; Moore, Virginia. ''The Madisons: A Biography.'' New York: McGraw-Hill, 1979. {{ISBN|0-07-042903-0}}</ref> Apparitions and the presence of otherworldly forces have been seen and felt in many places at The Octagon, including on the spiral staircase, the second floor landing, the third floor landing, the third floor bedroom, and the garden area in the rear.<ref name="Floyd" /> Among the eyewitnesses have been members of the public, and curators and other employees hired by the museum which owns the house.<ref name="Hauck" /> Two of Colonel Tayloe's daughters are said to haunt The Octagon.<ref name="Whitman">Whitman, William B. ''Washington, D.C. Off the Beaten Path: A Guide to Unique Places.'' 4th ed. Guilford, Conn.: Globe Pequot, 2007. {{ISBN|0-7627-4217-8}}</ref> The first allegedly died before the War of 1812. Colonel Tayloe and his daughter quarreled on the second floor landing over the girl's relationship with a British officer stationed in the city. When the daughter turned in anger to go down the stairs, she fell down the stairs (or over the railing; stories differ) and died. Her specter is allegedly seen crumpled at the bottom of the steps or on the stairs near the second floor landing, and sometimes exhibits itself as the light of a candle moving up the staircase.<ref name="Floyd">Floyd, Randall. ''In the Realm of Ghosts and Hauntings.'' Augusta, Ga.: Harbor House, 2002. {{ISBN|1-891799-06-1}}</ref> The other death, stories claim, occurred in 1817 or shortly thereafter. Another of Colonel Tayloe's daughters eloped with a young man, incurring her father's wrath. When she returned home to reconcile with her father, they argued on the third-floor landing. This daughter, too, fell to her death down the stairs (or over the railing), and her shade is alleged to haunt the third floor landing and stairs between the second and third floors.<ref name="Apkarian" />
The Octagon is also believed by some to be haunted by the spirits of African American slaves who once lived there.<ref name="Landmarks" /> When the house held bells to summon servants, the spirits of the dead slaves would announce their presence by ringing these bells loudly.<ref name="Lockwood">[https://books.google.com/books?id=hoQ-AAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_v2_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q=&f=false Lockwood, Mary Smith. ''Historic Homes in Washington: Its Noted Men and Women.''] New York: Belford Company, 1889.</ref> The ghostly bell ringing first occurred in the 1870s. General [[George D. Ramsay]], Chief of Ordnance for the [[United States Army]] and commander of the [[Fort Lesley J. McNair|Washington Arsenal]] in Washington, D.C., was attending a dinner at The Octagon when all the bells in the house began ringing. As Marian Gouverneur, wife of Samuel Laurence Gouverneur, Jr. (the first American [[Consul (representative)|consul]] in [[Fuzhou|Foo Chow]], [[China]]), related the story, General Ramsay seized the bell ropes to stop the bells from sounding, but to everyone's shock they did not stop ringing.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=4wklAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_v2_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q=&f=false Gouverneur, Marian. ''As I Remember: Recollections of American Society During the Nineteenth Century.''] New York: D. Appleton and Company, 1911.</ref> Although Gouverneur's report was not made until 1911, the mysterious ringing of the bells had been reported in 1874<ref name="Clemmer">[https://books.google.com/books?id=88gLAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_v2_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q=&f=false Clemmer, Mary. ''Ten Years in Washington: Life and Scenes in the National Capital as a Woman Sees Them.''] Cincinnati: Queen City Publishing Company, 1874.</ref> and again in 1889,<ref name="Lockwood" /> each time attributed to the spirits of dead slaves.
Other spirits are also said to remain at The Octagon as well. Dolley Madison's spirit has been seen near the fireplace in the main ballroom as well as heading through a closed door to the garden, and her ghost's presence is accompanied by the smell of lilacs, her favorite flower.<ref>''Let's Go Washington.'' New York: Macmillan, 2003. {{ISBN|0-312-32001-9}}</ref> A slave girl in the house was allegedly thrown from the third floor landing to the first floor below and killed by a British soldier during the War of 1812, and eyewitnesses have reported hearing her scream.<ref name="Evelyn">Evelyn, Douglas E.; Dickson, Paul; and Ackerman, S.J. ''On This Spot: Pinpointing the Past in Washington, D.C.'' 3rd rev. ed. Dulles, Va.: Capital Books, 2008. {{ISBN|1-933102-70-5}}</ref> The specter of a British soldier in War of 1812 dress was seen by caretaker James Cypress in the 1950s, and museum superintendent Alric H. Clay claimed that in the 1960s spirits would often turn on the lights and open The Octagon's doors late at night.<ref name="Evelyn" /> A gambler shot to death in the house's third-floor bedroom in the late 19th century has sometimes been seen still in the bed he died in,<ref name="Ogden" /> and ghostly footmen have been seen at the front door waiting to receive guests.<ref name="Hauck" /> He was said to have rung a bell shortly before his death and that the ring of the bell often heard in the house is from him. Various witnesses have also reported hearing assorted moans, screams, and footsteps.<ref name="Floyd" />
===Independence Avenue SW=== [[File:Orville Wright Federal Building (3363883616).jpg|thumb|left|Wilbur Wright FAA HQ - probable site for Yellow House slave pen]] The spirits of slaves are also said to haunt a portion of [[Independence Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|Independence Avenue SW]], the site of two of the city's largest and most notorious slave markets. The Yellow House or Williams Slave Pen (at about 800 Independence Avenue SW, now the site of the headquarters of the [[Federal Aviation Administration]])<ref name = "FAA/Kraus">{{cite web|last1=Kraus|first1=Theresa L.|title=Was FAA HQ the Site of a Notorious Slave Pen?|url=https://www.faa.gov/about/history/milestones/media/Was_FAA_HQ_the_Site_of_a_Notorious_Slave_Pen.pdf|publisher=[[Federal Aviation Administration]]|accessdate=December 7, 2016}}</ref> was the most notorious slave pen in the capital: A modest, well-maintained, two-story yellow house concealed a very large basement in which slaves were chained to walls in windowless rooms, while a {{convert|30|sqft|m2}} yard surrounded by a {{convert|12|ft|m|adj=on}} high brick wall provided space for the training and selling of slaves.<ref>Blackman, Ann. ''Wild Rose: Rose O'Neale Greenhow, Civil War Spy.'' Reprint ed. New York: Random House, 2006. {{ISBN|0-8129-7045-4}}; Bangura, Abdul Karim. ''Historical Political Economy of Washington.'' Latham, Md.: University Press of America, 2000. {{ISBN|0-7618-1707-7}}</ref> Another large slave market, the Robey Slave Pen, was just a block away<ref name = "FAA/Kraus"/> at the corner of 7th Street SW and Independence Avenue SW.<ref name="Goode">Goode, James W. ''Capital Losses: A Cultural History of Washington's Destroyed Buildings.'' 2d ed. Washington, D.C.: Smithsonian Books, 2003. {{ISBN|1-58834-105-4}}; Deyle, Steven. ''Carry Me Back: The Domestic Slave Trade in American Life.'' New York: Oxford University Press US, 2005. {{ISBN|0-19-516040-1}}</ref> On dark nights, witnesses say they have heard the clinking of chains and screams on Independence Avenue where these slave pens used to operate.<ref name="Jordan" /><ref>Rooney, E. Ashley and Johnston, Betsy. ''Washington, D.C.: Ghosts, Legends, and Lore.'' Atglen, Pa.: Schiffer Publishing, 2008. {{ISBN|0-7643-2961-8}}</ref>
===Chinatown=== [[File:Mary E. Surratt House.JPG|thumb|150px|[[Mary E. Surratt Boarding House|Mary Surratt's boarding house]] in Chinatown, Washington, D.C.]] The intersection of 7th Street NW and H Street NW is the heart of D.C.'s [[Chinatown, Washington, D.C.|Chinatown]] neighborhood today, but prior to the 1930s it was populated primarily by [[Germans|German]] immigrants.<ref>Brown, Jules. ''Rough Guide to Washington DC.'' 3d ed. New York: Rough Guides, 2002. {{ISBN|1-85828-884-3}}; Price, Marie and Benton-Short, Lisa. ''Migrants to the Metropolis: The Rise of Immigrant Gateway Cities.'' Syracuse, N.Y.: Syracuse University Press, 2008. {{ISBN|0-8156-3186-3}}</ref> Before the [[American Civil War]], 7th Street NW was the city's primary commercial district, the street lined with three-story [[Federal architecture|Federal-style]] [[Townhouse#Canada and United States|townhouses]] with shops on the ground floor and residences above.<ref>Penczer, Peter R. ''Washington, D.C., Past and Present.'' Arlington, Va.: Oneonta Press, 1998. {{ISBN|0-9629841-1-6}}</ref> Lincoln conspirator [[Mary Surratt]]'s boarding house (604 H Street NW) has been substantially renovated through the years (and currently houses a [[Chinese restaurant]]), but it may also house Mary Surratt's ghost.<ref name="Alexander" /> From the 1870s onward, occupants of the building have claimed that Surratt's spirit is responsible for the incomprehensible mumbling and whispers, footsteps, muffled sobs, and creaking floorboards which have unnerved them.<ref>Taylor, L.B. ''The Ghosts of Virginia.'' Williamsburg, Va.: Virginia Ghosts, 1996. {{ISBN|0-9628271-4-2}}</ref>
===National Theatre and National Building Museum=== {{Multiple image |align=left |direction=vertical |width=180 |image1=National Theatre & Freedom Plaza - Washington, DC.jpg |caption1=National Theatre |image2=National Building Museum - atrium.JPG |caption2=Interior of the National Building Museum, showing the building's Corinthian columns }} At least three other sites in downtown D.C. are also reputed to be haunted. The [[National Theatre (Washington, D.C.)|National Theatre]] (1321 Pennsylvania Avenue NW) opened at its current location on December 7, 1835, although the old building was torn down and replaced with the current structure in 1923.<ref>Lee, Douglas Bennett; Meersman, Roger L.; and Murphy, Donn B. ''Stage for a Nation: The National Theatre, 150 Years.'' Lanham, Md.: Publisher University Press of America, 1985. {{ISBN|0-8191-5021-5}}</ref> Nonetheless, some claim the theater is haunted by the ghost of actor John McCullough, who was murdered in the 1880s by a fellow thespian where the modern stage is located today.<ref>Wurman, Richard Saul. ''Washington, DC Access.'' 3d ed. New York: Access Press, 1992. {{ISBN|0-06-277039-X}}</ref> The spook was first sighted by Frederic Bond, a comic actor and friend of McCullough's, in September 1896. Bond was on the stage late at night reviewing preparations for the next day's performance when he felt a spectral presence that terrified him. He then saw a ghostly figure dressed in the traditional garb of the Shakespearean character [[Hamlet]]. Recognizing the spirit, he shouted McCullough's name and the ghost vanished.<ref>Moran, Mark and Sceurman, Mark. ''Weird U.S.: Your Travel Guide to America's Local Legends and Best Kept Secrets.'' New York: Sterling Publishing Company, Inc., 2004. {{ISBN|0-7607-5043-2}}; Wilmeth, Don B. and Bigsby, C.W.E. ''The Cambridge History of American Theatre.'' Reprint ed. New York: Cambridge University Press, 1999. {{ISBN|0-521-65179-4}}</ref> The [[National Building Museum]] (401 F Street NW), too, is allegedly haunted. Built in 1887 in order to process pensions for Civil War veterans, widows, and orphans (such pensions consumed a quarter of the federal budget at the time), the "Pension Building" (as it was originally known) contains 15 [[Corinthian order|Corinthian columns]] made of brick and plaster and painted to imitate black [[onyx]].<ref>Moeller, Gerard and Weeks, Christopher. ''AIA Guide to the Architecture of Washington, D.C.'' 4th ed. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press, 2006. {{ISBN|0-8018-8468-3}}</ref> Security guards and other witnesses have claimed that the swirling colors of the columns can change to form the outlines of people who have recently died, or who had ties to the building.<ref name="Hauck" /> When in use as the headquarters of the [[Superior Court of the District of Columbia]] in the 1940s, night watchmen reported seeing a man on horseback on the upper floors, where horses used to be quartered during the Civil War.<ref name="Alexander" /> They also reported seeing the ghost of James Tanner, a stenographer who took down the testimony of eyewitnesses after the assassination of President Lincoln at Ford's Theater (ironically, Robert Todd Lincoln approved the plans for the Pension Building).<ref name="Alexander" /> These stories gained such prominence that mystery writer Margaret Truman mentioned them in one of her novels.<ref>Truman, Margaret. ''Murder on the Potomac.'' Reprint ed. New York: Random House, 1995. {{ISBN|0-449-21937-2}} p. 314.</ref>
===Hay-Adams Hotel=== [[File:Hay-Adams Hotel DC.JPG|thumb|Hay-Adams Hotel]] The [[Hay–Adams Hotel]] may also be host to the ghost of [[Marian Hooper Adams|Marian "Clover" Hooper Adams]]. She was the wife of [[Henry Brooks Adams]], the celebrated 19th-century American [[journalist]], [[historian]], [[academia|academic]] and [[novelist]] who was the grandson of John Quincy Adams.<ref name="Friedrich">Friedrich, Otto. ''Clover: The Tragic Love Story of Clover and Henry Adams and Their Brilliant Life in America's Gilded Age.'' New York: Simon & Schuster, 1979. {{ISBN|978-0-671-22509-4}}</ref> She married Henry Adams on June 27, 1872, and in 1877 the couple moved to Washington, D.C., and rented the Slidell House at 1607 H Street NW.<ref name="Wills">[[Garry Wills|Wills, Garry]]. ''Henry Adams and the Making of America.'' Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co., 2005. {{ISBN|0-618-13430-1}}</ref> Their home became a [[Salon (gathering)|salon]] for the capital's [[Intellectual|literati]] and politically powerful.<ref name="Wills" /> In 1881, the Adamses purchased a lot on the northwest corner of [[16th Street Northwest (Washington, D.C.)|16th Street NW]] and [[H Street (Washington, D.C.)|H Street NW]] on Lafayette Square, and with their friend [[John Hay]] began building the famous [[Hay-Adams Houses]]—two of the most architecturally important private residences ever built in the city.<ref name="Goode" /> Marian Adams' beloved father, to whom she was exceptionally close, died on April 13, 1885, and she sank into a deep [[Clinical depression|depression]].<ref name="Friedrich" /> Just months before she was to occupy her spacious and luxurious new home, Adams committed suicide on December 6, 1885, by swallowing [[potassium cyanide]].<ref name="Goode" /> To mark her grave in [[Rock Creek Cemetery]], Henry Adams commissioned sculptor [[Augustus Saint-Gaudens]] and architect [[Stanford White]] to create the haunting [[Adams Memorial (grave marker)|Adams Memorial]] with its hooded, robed, androgynous figure formally titled ''Mystery of the Hereafter and The Peace of God that Passeth Understanding'' (but which is commonly called ''Grief'').<ref name="Wills" /> The Hay-Adams Houses were razed in 1927 by [[real estate developer]] [[Harry Wardman]], and the Hay-Adams Hotel built on the site.<ref name="Bednar" /> Although Marian Adams never lived in the house where the Hay-Adams Hotel is today, some hotel staff say her specter haunts the site. Housekeepers and other staff have reported being hugged by an invisible presence as well as hearing a woman sobbing.<ref name="Morgan">[http://abcnews.go.com/Travel/story?id=118686 Morgan, David. "Check Into a Haunted Hotel This Halloween."] ''ABC News.'' October 21, 2002.</ref> Other mysterious occurrences attributed to the Adams specter include locked doors opening and closing, clock radios turning on and off, and a woman's voice whispering, "What do you want?"<ref name="Tischler" /> A few witnesses say the ghost is accompanied by the scent of [[mimosa]], Adams' favorite scent.<ref name="Caggiula" /> The incidents are located primarily on the hotel's fourth floor,<ref name="SunTimes">[http://www.suntimes.com/news/politics/obama/1358051,CST-NWS-obama01.article Ihejirika, Maudlyne. "Obama's 'Haunted' House."] ''Chicago Sun-Times.'' January 1, 2009.</ref> and occur usually during the first two weeks of December (near the anniversary of Marian Adams' death).<ref name="Morgan" />
==Dupont Circle==
===Walsh Mansion=== [[File:Embassy of Indonesia, Washington.jpg|thumb|left|The former Walsh Mansion (now the Indonesian Embassy) near Dupont Circle]] One of the most important buildings in the [[Dupont Circle, Washington, D.C.|Dupont Circle]] neighborhood is the [[Walsh Mansion]] (now the Embassy of Indonesia) located at 2020 [[Massachusetts Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|Massachusetts Avenue NW]]. [[Thomas Walsh (miner)|Thomas J. Walsh]] had emigrated penniless from Ireland to the United States in 1869, then over the next quarter century built up a small fortune as a [[Carpentry|carpenter]], [[Underground mining (hard rock)|miner]], and [[hotel manager]].<ref name="Lorenz">Lorenz, Marjorie. ''Notorious Women of the West: The Good, the Bad and the Eccentric.'' Dover, Del.: Cherokee Books, 2005. {{ISBN|1-930052-27-8}}</ref> His first daughter (born in 1880) died in infancy, but his daughter, Evalyn (born in 1886), and son, Vinson (born in 1888), both survived.<ref name="James" /> He lost nearly all his life's savings in the [[Panic of 1893]].<ref name="Lorenz" /> The family moved to [[Ouray, Colorado]], in 1896, where Walsh bought the [[Camp Bird Mine]] (which was thought to have been worked out) and struck a massive vein of gold and silver.<ref name="Kurin">Kurin, Richard. ''Hope Diamond: The Legendary History of a Cursed Gem.'' New York: HarperCollins, 2006. {{ISBN|0-06-087351-5}}</ref> Now a multi-millionaire, Thomas Walsh moved his family to Washington, D.C., in 1898.<ref name="Lorenz" /> After spending 1899–1900 in [[Paris]], [[France]], the Walshes returned to Washington where Thomas Walsh commenced the construction of a mansion on Massachusetts Avenue NW.<ref name="Field">Field, Cynthia R.; Gournay, Isabelle; and Somma, Thomas P. ''Paris on the Potomac: The French Influence on the Architecture and Art of Washington.'' Columbus, Ohio: Ohio University Press, 2007. {{ISBN|0-8214-1760-6}}</ref> The Walsh Mansion, completed in 1903,<ref>Williams, Paul. ''Dupont Circle.'' Mount Pleasant, S.C.: Arcadia Publishing, 2000. {{ISBN|0-7385-0633-8}}</ref> cost $835,000 (the most expensive residence in the city at the time)<ref name="Kurin" /> and had 60 rooms, a theater, a ballroom, a French salon, a grand staircase, and $2 million in furnishings which took several years to purchase and install.<ref name="Field" /> Evalyn Walsh married [[Edward Beale McLean|Edward Beale "Ned" McLean]] (the publishing heir whose family owned ''[[The Washington Post]]'') in 1908, and after her father's death in April 1910 lived in the Walsh Mansion.<ref name="James">James, Edward T. ''Notable American Women, 1607–1950: A Biographical Dictionary.'' Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press, 1971. {{ISBN|0-674-62734-2}}</ref> In 1910, Ned McLean bought the allegedly [[curse]]d [[Hope Diamond]] for his wife for $180,000 (although the purchase was not formalized until February 1911, and not completed until after a lawsuit settled out of court in 1912).<ref name="Kurin" /> Evalyn Walsh died on April 26, 1947.<ref name="James" /> To cover Evalyn's significant debts, the Walsh Mansion was sold in 1952 to the Government of [[Indonesia]] for use as an embassy.<ref name="Kurin" /> But according to embassy staff, Evalyn Walsh McLean never vacated the home. Rather, her spirit has been seen several times gliding down the mansion's grand central staircase.<ref name="Hauck" /> A naked lady's spectral form has also been seen from time to time in the mansion, but no one knows who she is.<ref>Holzer, Hans. ''The Ghosts That Walk in Washington.'' Garden City, New York: Doubleday & Company, Inc., 1971. p.230</ref>
===Woodrow Wilson House=== [[File:Woodrow Wilson House.JPG|thumb|Woodrow Wilson House]] A second noted house in the Dupont Circle neighborhood which is claimed to be haunted is the [[Woodrow Wilson House (Washington, D.C.)|Woodrow Wilson House]] (2340 S Street NW). [[Woodrow Wilson]] was elected President of the United States in 1912, was re-elected in 1916 promising to keep the nation out of war, led the nation through [[World War I]], and left office in 1921.<ref name="Brands">Brands, H.W. ''Woodrow Wilson.'' New York: Macmillan, 2003. {{ISBN|0-8050-6955-0}}</ref> At 2 AM on September 26, 1919, while traveling to [[Wichita, Kansas]], on a nationwide speaking tour to win public support to pressure the Senate into ratifying the [[Treaty of Versailles]], Wilson collapsed and, after cancelling the rest of his speaking tour, was rushed back to the capital by train.<ref name="Knock">Knock, Thomas J. ''To End All Wars: Woodrow Wilson and the Quest for a New World Order.'' Paperback ed. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press, 1995. {{ISBN|0-691-00150-2}}; Park, Bert E. ''The Impact of Illness of World Leaders.'' Philadelphia, Pa.: University of Pennsylvania Press, 1986. {{ISBN|978-0-8122-8005-0}}; Hoover, Herbert. ''The Ordeal of Woodrow Wilson.'' Reprint ed. Princeton, N.J.: Woodrow Wilson Center Press, 1992. {{ISBN|0-943875-41-2}}; Weinstein, Edwin A. ''Woodrow Wilson: A Medical and Psychological Biography.'' Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press, 1981. {{ISBN|978-0-691-04683-9}}</ref> His condition worsened on the journey, and upon arriving at the White House on October 2 the President suffered a life-threatening [[stroke]] that left him [[Hemiplegia|permanently paralyzed]] on his left side and [[Hemianopsia|blind in the left eye]].<ref name="Knock" /> Although the President lived, he was confined to bed for two months, seen only by his wife, a few close associates, and his physicians.<ref name="McDermott">McDermott, Rose. ''Presidential Leadership, Illness, and Decision Making.'' New York: Cambridge University Press, 2007. {{ISBN|0-521-88272-9}}; Gilbert, Robert E. ''The Mortal Presidency: Illness and Anguish in the White House.'' 2d ed. New york: Fordham University Press, 1998. {{ISBN|0-8232-1837-6}}</ref> From December 1919 to April 1920 Wilson required a wheelchair.<ref name="Knock" /> Wilson attended his first [[United States Cabinet|Cabinet]] meeting in April 1920, but for the rest of the year his mind continued to wander, his memory was marred, and he tired easily.<ref name="McDermott" /> By March 1921 (when he left office) Wilson was able to walk short distances with the use of a cane (and with a valet close at hand).<ref name="Knock" /> The extent of Wilson's disability was kept from the public until after his death on February 3, 1924.<ref name="Cheering">Smith, Gene. ''When the Cheering Stopped: The Last Years of Woodrow Wilson.'' New York: William Morrow and Company, 1964. {{ISBN|978-0-688-06011-4}}</ref> President and Mrs. Wilson purchased a large home at 2340 S Street NW, to which a number of modifications were made (including the addition of an elevator).<ref name="Cheering" /> Woodrow Wilson received few guests in his last years, and died in his third floor bedroom on February 3, 1924.<ref name="Brands" /> His wife, [[Edith Bolling Galt Wilson]], lived in the home until her death on December 28, 1961, and willed the home to the [[National Trust for Historic Preservation]] to be made into a museum honoring her husband. In the decades since her death, staff and visitors at the Woodrow Wilson House claim to have seen the President's ghost sitting in his rocking chair, heard the shuffle of a man walking with a cane, and heard a man sob.<ref>Conroy, Sarah Booth. "The Ghost List; Washington's Spirited Presidential Tradition." ''Washington Post.'' October 30, 2000; Shank, Terry Sue. "Washington Haunts: Ghostly Wisps at Famous Sites Recall the Legends of History." ''Baltimore Sun.'' June 28, 1992; Conroy, Sarah Booth. "Homing In On Woodrow Wilson." ''Washington Post.'' March 18, 1996; "Tour Tells Tales of Eerie Haunts." ''Washington Times.'' October 31, 1990.</ref>
==Georgetown== General [[Edward Braddock]] left [[Georgetown University Astronomical Observatory|Observatory Hill]] in [[Georgetown, Washington, D.C.|Georgetown]] in 1755 on an expedition to capture the [[France|French]] [[Fort Duquesne]] during the [[French and Indian War]].<ref name="Landmarks">[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1891/01/04/103289475.pdf "Old Landmarks at the Capital That Few Persons Know Anything About."] ''New York Times.'' January 4, 1891.</ref><ref>Froncek, Thomas. ''The City of Washington: An Illustrated History.'' New York: Random House Value Publishing, 1992. {{ISBN|0-517-07390-0}}; Farquhar, Roger Brooke. ''Historic Montgomery County, Maryland: Old Homes and History.'' Silver Spring, Md.: Roger Brooke Farquhar, 1952.</ref> [[Braddock expedition|Braddock's expedition]] was surprised on July 9 in the vicinity of present-day [[Braddock, Pennsylvania]], in what is now known as the [[Battle of the Monongahela]]. Nearly 900 of Braddock's 1,300 men were killed or wounded, and Braddock himself killed. Since before the [[American Civil War]],<ref name="Alexander" /> witnesses say that on the anniversary of Braddock's departure they can hear shouted military orders, horses' hooves on cobblestones, the sound of men marching, and the sound of metal clanking against metal.<ref name="Hauck">Hauck, Dennis. ''Haunted Places: The National Directory.'' 2d ed. New York: Penguin Group, 2002. {{ISBN|0-14-200234-8}}</ref> The sounds can be heard near [[14th Street Bridge (Potomac River)|the old Long Bridge]] or near the Georgetown bluffs overlooking the Potomac River.<ref name="Alexander" />
[[File:Halcyon House.JPG|thumb|left|Halcyon House]] [[Halcyon House]] (3400 Prospect Street NW) is a {{convert|30000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} mansion originally built in 1787 by [[Benjamin Stoddert]], the first [[United States Secretary of the Navy|Secretary of the Navy]].<ref name="AIAGuide">Moeller, Gerard Martin and Weeks, Christopher. ''AIA Guide to the Architecture of Washington, D.C.'' 4th ed. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press, 2006. {{ISBN|0-8018-8468-3}}</ref><ref name="200Years">[https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/27/garden/house-proud-200-years-of-house-17-years-of-renovation.html Gamarekian, Barbara. "200 Years of House, 17 Years of Renovation."] ''New York Times.'' July 27, 1995.</ref> Halcyon House was owned by several individuals in the 19th century, and is alleged to have served as part of the [[Underground Railroad]].<ref>Guiley, Rosemary. ''The Guinness Encyclopedia of Ghosts and Spirits.'' London: Guinness Publishing, 1994. {{ISBN|0-85112-748-7}}</ref> The home was sold in 1900 to Albert Clemens, a nephew of [[Mark Twain]].<ref name="AIAGuide" /> The original structure was heavily altered over the next 38 years.
